Problem:
We have a LTI (Linear Time-Invariant) system characterized by the linear operator \\( L \\) acting on a function \\( x(t) \\), resulting in \\( Lx(t) = y(t) \\). In addition, we consider the Laplace transform \\( \\mathcal{L} \\{x(t)\\} = X(s) \\) and its inverse transformation applied to \\( X(s) \\).

If we apply a Laplace transform to \\( x(t) \\) resulting in \\( X(s) \\) and then inverse transform \\( X(s) \\) back to \\( x(t) \\), will the solution \\( y(t) = Lx(t) \\) at time T be the same if \\( x(t) \\) had not undergone the transformations?
Explanation: The Laplace transform and its inverse are linear and bijective operations. Applying these transformations to \\( x(t) \\) and then reversing them yields the original function \\( x(t) \\) exactly, meaning \\( y(t) = Lx(t) \\) remains unchanged after these transformations.
